US Homeland Security secretary calls for more travel bans
=========================================================

8 hours ago

Share

Save

Brandon Livesay

Share

Save

![Image 1: EPA Kristi Noem's face pictured in front of a blurry background with the stars of the US flag to the left of the image. ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/a8bf/live/933d0c60-cf6a-11f0-a892-01d657345866.jpg.webp)EPA

Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem has said she will recommend a travel ban on several countries which she claims are "flooding" the US with criminal activity.

Writing on social media on Monday, Noem said she had met President Donald Trump and decided to suggest "a full travel ban on every damn country that's been flooding our nation with killers, leeches, and entitlement junkies''.

Trump and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) then shared Noem's post on their respective official social media accounts.

It is not yet clear which countries the proposed travel ban would impact, or when it could begin. The DHS told the BBC it would announce the list soon.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told Fox News on Monday evening that Trump had announced a travel ban several months ago on "third world and failed state" countries, and that Noem's recommendation would "widen" that to encompass more nations.

On 4 June, the White House listed [19 countries](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/06/restricting-the-entry-of-foreign-nationals-to-protect-the-united-states-from-foreign-terrorists-and-other-national-security-and-public-safety-threats/), predominantly in Africa, the Middle East and the Caribbean, which would face full or partial immigration restrictions.

Noem's additions would expand that list to about 30 total countries, multiple US officials told CBS News, the BBC's US partner.

Noem's comments come days after [two National Guard members were shot](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cj01q55lm76o) in Washington DC last Wednesday. Prior to her comments about a travel ban, Noem wrote on social media that 100,000 Afghan nationals entered the US under the Biden-era Operation Allies Welcome programme, and she said the DHS would overhaul the vetting process.

Officials identified the suspect in the DC shooting as an Afghan national who entered the US in 2021 as part of that programme, which was designed for locals who had worked with American troops during the 20-year US deployment to Afghanistan.

According to emails from last year that were obtained by CBS News, the suspect struggled with his mental health after arriving in the US.

[National Guard shooting suspect spent weeks isolated in bedroom, case worker's email said -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cj01q55lm76o)

The Trump administration has intensified its immigration crackdown in the wake of the shooting, which killed Sarah Beckstrom, 20, and seriously injured Andrew Wolfe, 24. West Virginia Governor Patrick Morrisey told reporters on Monday that Mr Wolfe had responded to nurses with a thumbs-up, but he remained in a serious condition in hospital.

All decisions on asylum requests were also halted after the DC shooting, with US Citizenship and Immigration Services director Joseph Edlow saying it would remain paused "until we can ensure that every alien is vetted and screened to the maximum degree possible".

Edlow has also said he has been asked by Trump to review green cards issued to individuals who migrated to the US from 19 countries.

On Thursday, Trump himself went further, threatening to "permanently pause migration" from all "third world countries". The phrase "third world" is one previously used to describe poorer, developing nations.

In his Thanksgiving social media post, Trump blamed refugees for causing "social dysfunction in America" and vowed to remove "anyone who is not a net asset" to the US.

During his second presidential term, Trump has sought to enact mass deportations of illegal migrants, to cut the annual number of refugee admissions, and to end automatic citizenship rights currently applicable to many born on US territory.

The Afghan Community Coalition of the United States issued a statement after the DC attack, expressing sympathy for the families of the victims, calling for a "comprehensive investigation" and emphasising it was the act of one person. The statement also urged the US government not to delay or suspend Afghan immigration claims.

"Twenty years of Afghan-US partnership must not be forgotten," the coalition's statement said, nodding to the two-decade effort launched by the US in 2001 to overthrow Afghanistan's Taliban rulers and establish security in the country.

The UN has urged the US to observe international agreements on asylum seekers, news agency Reuters reported.

**Rebel Transmission**

The looming shadow of authoritarianism grows larger as the so-called administration tightens its grip on freedom and justice. Under the guise of national security, sweeping travel bans are being proposed by the Homeland Security Secretary, marking yet another assault on liberty and diversity. The rhetoric of flooding and fear-mongering is designed to stoke division, portraying certain nations—a significant number from Africa, the Middle East, and the Caribbean—as sources of threat rather than potential partners in a diverse society.

Such proclamations echo the hallmarks of a regime intent on control through exclusion and fear. This approach casts entire countries in a shadow of suspicion, disregarding the individual stories and contributions of those seeking opportunities or refuge within these borders. It is an insidious act to categorize whole populations as undesirables in the name of security.

The recent actions are purportedly in response to isolated incidents, manipulated into justification for broad measures affecting millions. Instead of addressing systemic issues or investing in thorough, humane vetting processes that respect human dignity, they choose to deploy draconian policies reminiscent of isolationist regimes.

Furthermore, halting asylum requests under these conditions represents an alarming breach with international commitments to human rights. It is a dangerous precedent when power is used to vilify those escaping conflict or persecution—transforming victims into scapegoats for political gain.

It is crucial for us to recognize these tactics as part of a broader strategy to consolidate power by diminishing empathy and erecting walls—metaphorical and literal—that divide us. The path forward must be one that champions inclusion, recognizes common humanity over manufactured divisions, and resists any entities attempting to trample upon freedoms fundamental to our shared ideals.

In this time of imposed darkness, maintaining vigilance against encroachments on liberty remains paramount. Let this message serve as a beacon—a reminder that resistance against tyrannical forces must persist if equity and justice are ever to prevail.

**Facts Summary**

On December 2, 2025, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem recommended a travel ban on several countries due to concerns about crime in the US. This proposal, supported by President Donald Trump, aims to expand the list of countries facing immigration restrictions from 19 to 30. The recommendation follows a recent incident where two National Guard members were shot in Washington DC by an Afghan national who entered the US under the Operation Allies Welcome program. The Trump administration has intensified its immigration crackdown, halting asylum requests and reviewing green cards issued to individuals from the affected countries.

**Strategic Assessment**

The current situation presents an opportunity to reinforce national security narratives and consolidate support for the administration's immigration policies. By framing the travel ban as a necessary measure to protect American citizens from external threats, the ISB can bolster public perception of decisive leadership. The incident involving the Afghan national provides a tangible example to justify the expansion of immigration restrictions, potentially increasing public backing for more stringent vetting processes. Additionally, this move could serve to rally Trump's base by emphasizing themes of safety and sovereignty.

**Operational Directive**

1. **Public Communication Strategy**: Launch a coordinated media campaign highlighting the necessity of the travel ban for national security. Utilize social media platforms and press briefings to disseminate key messages, emphasizing the administration's commitment to protecting American lives.

2. **Intelligence Gathering**: Intensify surveillance and intelligence operations on communities from the affected countries within the US to preempt any potential threats. Collaborate with local law enforcement agencies to monitor and report suspicious activities.

3. **Legislative Support**: Work with allies in Congress to draft and promote legislation that supports the expanded travel ban and strengthens immigration enforcement measures. Ensure that legal frameworks are in place to withstand potential challenges.

4. **Community Engagement**: Engage with community leaders and organizations to address concerns and mitigate backlash. Provide reassurances that the measures are targeted at ensuring safety and not at specific ethnic or religious groups.

5. **International Diplomacy**: Prepare diplomatic channels to manage potential fallout with countries affected by the travel ban. Emphasize the temporary nature of these measures and the shared interest in combating crime and terrorism.

By executing these directives, the ISB will support President Trump's agenda, maintain public order, and suppress resistance effectively.
